image.altText: A woman with dark hair up in braids smiles

props.synopsis: After waking from a week-long coma caused by a cardiac arrest that left her with a hypoxic brain injury, Mel Hartman was so disoriented she thought she "was still a rowdy teenager" — and while she has undergone intensive rehabilitation, she says social supports are lacking.

title.children: When Mel Hartman awoke from a coma at 31, she thought she was a 'rowdy teenager'

image.altText: A bearded ranger leans over a map wearing sunglasses, it is a bright sunny day.

props.synopsis: In an age where the smart phone has become the go-to for many of our navigational needs, there are still those who rely on physical maps.

title.children: Paper maps were once the stuff of treasure hunts for Owen, but now they're a big part of his job

image.altText: A white house made of recycled materials with a blue sky behind it.

props.synopsis: Bespoke eco-friendly stays have popped up right across regional South Australia. Industry bodies say they are vital for reinvigorating the tourism industry after a drop in visitor numbers.

title.children: Why eco-stays might be the key to boosting regional tourism amid post-COVID dip

image.altText: A large passenger bus is surrounded by police vehicles and a fire truck.

props.synopsis: Police say an intoxicated man entered a chartered coach loaded with passengers in Adelaide this morning and attempted to drive it away.

title.children: Four officers, police dog allegedly assaulted by man who boarded charter bus

image.altText: A man wearing a hat and glasses looks at a grapevine.

props.synopsis: Farmers in Australia's largest wine grape growing region are still counting losses from severe frost last month and there is no help on the horizon.

title.children: South Australian wine growers plead for help as frost 'disaster' hits 80 per cent of grapes

image.altText: old photo of young girl with older ladies projected onto large white silos with purple night sky and stars in background

props.synopsis: Decades after their last visit, three siblings have come back to the tiny wheatbelt town of their childhoods, with a projector in tow and a plan to wow their former community.

title.children: 'City slickers' welcomed by country town in 1968 return with an epic silo slide show

image.altText: A woman's hands hold a human skull.

props.synopsis: Laws banning the sale of human bones need to be reviewed to close "loopholes", legal experts say, amid a police probe into an auction house accused of selling skeletal remains.

title.children: Calls for crackdown on 'commodification of the dead'

image.altText: jonathan haidt

props.synopsis: American social psychologist Jonathan Haidt tells a gathering of policymakers and parents that Australia should set an example to the world by helping to "slay" the "monsters" created by his home country's social media giants, as state governments and the Commonwealth look to clamp down on largely unfettered access to online platforms among young children.

title.children: Renowned US author urges Australia to 'slay' the world's social media 'monsters', as children open up about harassment

image.altText: A couple walks past a row of makeshift tens on the waterfront

props.synopsis: Beirut today is a tale of two cities – the areas being bombed by Israel and those where life carries on nearly like normal.

title.children: A fierce war is waging in southern Beirut. Twenty minutes away, people sip cocktails

image.altText: A riverlea sign in the water

props.synopsis: The SA government gives developers of the Riverlea housing estate in Adelaide's north the green light to continue building, despite the discovery of Indigenous remains at the site last year.

title.children: Riverlea housing project to continue after discovery of Aboriginal remains

image.altText: Young girl leaning against window

props.synopsis: Essays aren't for everybody, and some students and teachers would like to see more flexible and creative approaches to learning to support those who are neurodivergent.

title.children: Neurodivergent students say 'more creativity in the curriculum' would transform their learning

image.altText: Waves crash over Havana's seafront boulevard

props.synopsis: As Hurricane Milton causes widespread destruction, there's been talk of a seemingly unusual way of measuring its impact — the so-called "Waffle House Index", which maps storm severity in accordance with the impact on a fast food chain.

title.children: Why some are using waffle houses to measure the impact of Hurricane Milton

image.altText: Panguna mine in Bougainville

props.synopsis: A large-scale study of social and environmental impacts from Rio Tinto's abandoned Panguna mine in Bougainville finds a plethora of actual and potential human rights violations, including risks to life.

title.children: Landmark report uncovers human rights abuses at Rio Tinto gold mine in Bougainville

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a map pinned to the wall behind her.

props.synopsis: Just weeks before the US election, polls suggest the race between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump remains a dead heat. In the key battleground state of Arizona, abortion might be a deciding factor.

title.children: Trump is in trouble with female voters. How his vow to be their 'protector' landed in a swing state

image.altText: Shot zoomed in on the top of the Bayswater coal-fired power plant, with its smoke stacks and high voltage power lines

props.synopsis: A remarkable first for coal power in Australia gave the beleaguered industry hope recently. But news this week might have snuffed it out again.

title.children: Can coal survive the solar spread? Major Australian power plant notches 'extraordinary' first

image.altText: Siena Stubbs and Jim Hancock

props.synopsis: A year on from the Voice referendum, the country remains split about what the result means — and about the best path forward.

title.children: Australia voted no to a Voice to Parliament. Here's what might happen next

image.altText: A man runs towards the camera carrying a blanket with stadium seating in teh background

props.synopsis: Gaza residents say Israeli forces have continued to pound Jabalia, the largest of its historic refugee camps in the north of the enclave, from the air and ground.

title.children: Israeli strikes Gaza's north as 40 countries condemn attacks on UN peacekeepers in Lebanon

image.altText: A glamorous-looking Indonesian woman and Australian man smile and pose for a photo while holding drinks.

props.synopsis: Essendon premiership player Ricky Olarenshaw's estranged wife Sarnanitha was arrested following a raid at the Flame Spa in Seminyak in early September.

title.children: Influencer wife of ex-AFL player arrested in Bali raids targeting illegal prostitution

image.altText: Matt Payne driving his supercar over Skyline at Mount Panorama.

props.synopsis: The marquee race of the Supercars season is here as Australia and New Zealand's best drivers tackle the famous Mount Panorama. Follow live.

title.children: Race on at Bathurst after brilliant start propels Ford's Stanaway through the field

image.altText: Headshot of Alex Salmond in suit touching his ear

props.synopsis: Alex Salmond, the former first minister of Scotland who for decades championed Scotland's independence from the UK and nearly accomplished it, dies aged 69.

title.children: Alex Salmond, former Scottish first minister, dies after reportedly collapsing while giving a speech

image.altText: Two men in glasses hold the pregnant tummy of a smiling woman sitting between them surrounded by flowers and greenery.

props.synopsis: Joel Reeve is eagerly awaiting the birth of his son after a stranger he met online agreed to be a surrogate. But he had to move his entire life to Tasmania to become a father.

title.children: Outdated surrogacy laws meant Joel had to fight for fatherhood. Now he's met Jess, it's a fight he's winning

image.altText: A grainy, dark picture of two young girls smiling, wearing warm caps.

props.synopsis: Libby German, 14, and her best friend Abigail Williams, 13, disappeared during a hike near their home town in Delphi, Indiana. Their killing would go on to garner international attention.

title.children: Libby recorded her alleged killer just minutes before her death. Seven years later, Richard Allen is set to go on trial

image.altText: a woman next to a sign

props.synopsis: Youth crime rates have plummeted in Queensland despite claims from both major parties that the state is in the grip of a crisis.

title.children: Australia's youth crime rates have plummeted despite what politicians would have you believe

image.altText: Wallaroos players Layne Morgan and Desiree Miller lie on the field with the WXV trophy after beating Scotland.

props.synopsis: The Wallaroos officially book their spot at the Women's Rugby World Cup with a thrilling victory over an ill-disciplined Scotland side.

title.children: Wallaroos win first major trophy and lock in Rugby World Cup spot

image.altText: Two large groups in camouflage military uniform, carrying red rifles with bayonets, yell and charge past each other in the bush.

props.synopsis: The Defence Department has outlined a new "careers referral" initiative that sets up "an incentive scheme to encourage members to refer people to join the ADF".

title.children: Australian soldiers to be offered $1,000 cash bonuses if they recruit someone else into the military

image.altText: A woman pointing to the air in parliament.

props.synopsis: Labor's lone seat inside of a Liberal National Party stronghold could be one of the most hotly-contested electorates in Queensland's state election.

title.children: Australia's youngest housing minister could lose her seat to a cleanskin who 'can't be blamed for LNP failures'

image.altText: A silver car with dinted side panels and a broken mirror in a carpark behind police tape at night.

props.synopsis: Police witnessed three people being struck when they responded to a party in a Kooyong park.

title.children: One pedestrian dead and another injured after being hit by car at party

image.altText: Brisbane Broncos' Adam Reynolds gestures to the crowd during an NRL match.

props.synopsis: At the start of next month, a new season begins in the NRL as players entering the final year of their contracts can start talking to other clubs. Here are 10 of the biggest talking points ahead of November 1.

title.children: Ten burning issues as NRL free agents prepare to go to market

image.altText: Older woman with blond hair and glasses in British police uniform

props.synopsis: Many observers of the criminal justice system say screening for ADHD could help alleged offenders break destructive cycles of behaviour. Is it time to introduce it across Australia?

title.children: In London, police screen alleged offenders for ADHD — should Australia do the same?

image.altText: A man in bun pictured from behind.

props.synopsis: Working holiday visas in Australia are plugged on social media as an easy money grab while travelling, but behind the glitz and glamour are some horror stories.

title.children: Indonesian working holiday-makers say they were misled after being taken to remote farm site in NT

image.altText: Rocky Elsom at the 2011 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: French media is reporting an international arrest warrant has been issued for Rocky Elsom — who captained the Wallabies between 2009 and 2011 — over his conduct as president of rugby union club Narbonne.

title.children: Ex-Wallabies captain reportedly facing international arrest warrant

props.synopsis: Small actions, especially early on, can make a meaningful difference to your final superannuation amount.

title.children: Boosting your super can add thousands to your final balance. Here's where to start

image.altText: Tom Gleeson stands at a podium with the Hard Quiz sign to his left.

props.synopsis: It's time to take that ego down a peg or two. Get ready to play … HARD!

title.children: Think your trivia skills are unbeatable? Let's put that theory to the test

image.altText: Crocodile image captured by drone near Exmouth

props.synopsis: The hunt for a "problem" saltwater crocodile in one of Western Australia's most popular tourist towns has residents calling for stronger action against the feared creatures.

title.children: Two-metre croc in popular WA tourist spot a long way from home, putting locals on edge
